Award.AwardTitle: Magnetically Actuated Active Tuning of Plasmonic Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Yadong Yin of the University of California, Riverside, and his students incorporate magnetic actuation into noble metal nanostructures to achieve active tuning of plasmonic properties. A long-term goal of this research is the development of novel hybrid optical nanostructures with many technological applications in data storage, photonic devices, and chemical and biomedical sensors. The team studies two types of magnetic responsive plasmonic nanostructures: one involves magnetically induced assembly and disassembly of plasmonic nanoparticles and the other utilizes magnetic alignment of anisotropic noble metal nanostructures to achieve active tuning of the plasmonic properties. To enable reversible tuning of the plasmonic property, the surfaces of these metal nanoparticles are engineered to produce sufficiently repulsive interactions that can balance the magnetically induced attractive force and prevent permanent aggregation. New synthetic methods are developed to create many complex hybrid materials that are integrated with both magnetic and plasmonic properties, providing very useful tools for studying and controlling the plasmonic properties through the movement, rotation, and assembly of the metal nanoparticles.

The resulting hybrid materials find great use in practical applications that may have very positive impacts on our society, including novel visual displays, optical sensors, anticounterfeiting devices, therapeutic agents for tumors, targeted drug delivery, and many enhanced sensing and imaging devices. The project also targets expanding research-based learning at UCR and in the wider community by engaging high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in research. Undergraduate students are attracted to the research program through regular academic and summer internship programs, student clubs and organizations, and collaborative programs with local small liberal arts colleges. Undergraduate and graduate students are provided with opportunities to present their discoveries in national meetings and other public settings. Students are also encouraged to report their research activities and findings in the form of video presentations that can be shared with their classmates, friends, family members, and others on their social networks, thus disseminating research outcomes from the laboratory to the general public. Prof. Yin is also deeply involved in science fair competition in order to promote high school students' interests in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Surface plasmon resonance is the resonant oscillation of conduction electrons stimulated by incident light.  When it occurs on nanoscale particles, the electron oscillation is confined around the surface of particles, leading to sharp and intense absorption and scattering of light at particular wavelengths. The plasmonic effect has been studied extensively particularly on noble metal nanoparticles such as gold and silver as it holds great promise for a wide range of applications such as building novel optoelectronic devices, chemical and biological sensors, and photothermal therapeutic agents. Extensive research has been done to control the plasmonic properties by fabricating nanoparticles of well-defined composition, size, and shape as well as the interparticle arrangement. However, little attention has been made to the design and fabrication of materials with dynamically tunable plasmonic properties, although such materials may offer many new opportunities towards novel effective optical and electronic sensors and detectors. The objective of this project is to develop novel responsive optical materials by incorporating magnetic actuation into noble metal plasmonic nanostructures.  The first approach being explored is to use magnetic fields to induce assembly of plasmonic nanoparticles and tune the plasmonic property dynamically by controlling the plasmonic coupling among the particles in the assemblies.  The specific efforts include the exploration of the synthesis of magnetic/plasmonic hybrid nanoparticles, study of their assembly and disassembly behavior, and characterize their plasmonic responses in response to external magnetic fields. We have explored the synthesis of a number of well-defined plasmonic, magnetic, and plasmonic/magnetic hybrid nanostructures using novel solution-based chemical synthesis methods.  In particular, a templating method for the fabrication of magnetic/plasmonic hybrid nanostructures has been developed, which has the potential to be extended to the synthesis of many other hybrid nanomaterials. We then studied the assembly and disassembly of plasmonic nanoparticle in one-dimensional chain structures and explored tuning of the plasmon excitation through the interparticle near-field plasmon coupling effect.  The second approach is designed based on the angular dependence of anisotropically shaped nanostructures such as nanorods.  Dynamic control of plasmonic structures can be achieved by controlling the orientation of anisotropic noble metal nanostructures using external magnetic fields.  The initial efforts include the exploration of various synthetic methods to create the anisotropically shaped magnetic/plasmonic nanostructures, including surface attachment and templating methods.  We further demonstrated that selective excitation of the plasmon modes of the anisotropic nanostructures can be achieved through the manipulation of the field direction relative to the directions of incidence and polarization of light.  

To enhance the broad impact of the research to the society, we have also explored the applications of the developed materials for visual information displays, smart window, optical sensors, and security features. Education wise, in this project we focused on expanding research-based learning at the campus of University of California, Riverside and in the wider community.  A number of graduate students were trained with the research expertise in colloidal synthesis and optical tuning. Undergraduate and high school students, many of whom from underrepresented groups (minority and female), have been attracted to the research program through regular academic and summer internship programs.  These students were encouraged to summarize their research activities and findings in the form of video presentations, which greatly helped disseminate research outcomes from the laboratory to the general public. Undergraduate students and teachers from local small liberal arts colleges have also been engaged in the relevant research.
